member.name: T:Ace.Communication.Services.DeviceLedFlashPattern
member.summary: A list of eV+ device node LED flash patterns. On UL-rated amps, the amber LED is wired to the red LED. So, for example, the old green/red flash at config time now appears as slow amber flash. One exception: fast green flash gets mapped to amber SOLID ON.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.DeviceLedFlashPattern.RedSolid

member.summary: LED flashes red at a high rate.

member.summary: LED flashes red at a medium rate.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.DeviceLedFlashPattern.RedSlow
member.summary: LED flashes red at a slow rate.

member.summary: LED is solid green.

member.summary: LED flashes green at a high rate.

member.summary: LED flashes green at a medium rate.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.DeviceLedFlashPattern.GreenSlow
member.summary: LED flashes green at a slow rate.

member.summary: LED flashes red and green at a medium rate.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.ServoData.VPlusCommand
member.summary:
V+ command code. Valid commands are:
0: Current mode. Arg: DAC output.
1: Free mode. Arg: DAC output.
2: Position mode. Arg: Scaled position command.
3: Set position. Arg: Scaled position.
4: Amp command. Arg: 1 to enable, 0 to disable.
5: Cal mode. Arg: None.
7: Adjust position. Arg: Scaled position offset.
8: Clear latched errors. Arg: Bit mask to clear.
9: Drive motor. Arg: Scaled position.
0xF: NOP. Arg: None.
0x10: High power. Arg: 1 to turn on, 0 to turn off.
0x11: Brake rel. Arg: 1 to release, 0 to engage.
0x12: Velocity mode Arg: Target velocity.

member.name: T:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypeHeader
member.summary: PacketType structure. this struct is a head structure following with (PacketTypeNak or PacketTypePiggy) structure

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypeHeader.version
member.summary: Version of the packet A server will only response to a client with the same packet version number

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypeHeader.type
member.summary: Type of packet This is a descriptor of the packet information. It's describing the meaning of the packet. The supported formats are 4 for PTYNAK and 5 for PTYACR.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypeHeader.sequence
member.summary: Sequence number of the packet A sequence number must be unique for each packet. The sequence number is send with a packet and the other side response the ACK or the NACK with the same sequence number.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypeHeader.cookie
member.summary: The cookie is used an identifier of a complete transaction ( Request - ACK - Response - ACK ). This must be also a unique number. In the actual system, the cookie is kept as key of a lookup to be able to map the packet coming back to the server to a specific task.

member.summary: First byte of error message

member.summary: Version of the packet A server will only response to a client with the same packet version number

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypePiggy.type
member.summary: Type of packet This is a descriptor of the packet information. It's describing the meaning of the packet. The supported formats are 4 for PTYNAK and 5 for PTYACR.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypePiggy.sequence
member.summary: Sequence number of the packet A sequence number must be unique for each packet. The sequence number is send with a packet and the other side response the ACK or the NACK with the same sequence number.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.PacketTypePiggy.cookie
member.summary: The cookie is used an identifier of a complete transaction ( Request - ACK - Response - ACK ). This must be also a unique number. In the actual system, the cookie is kept as key of a lookup to be able to map the packet coming back to the server to a specific task.

member.name: T:Ace.Communication.Services.EventBridge.SwappableFloat
member.summary: Bug 7958 When the swapped value is NaN, Windows changes some bits in it for some reason. The swapped value remains a NaN but the value is changed. Thus we must not swap float values if there is a risk to generate a NaN value. Using an union will prevent Windows to change the mantissa bits of the NaN float value.

member.name: M:Ace.Communication.Services.VPlusServer.Abstraction.Parameters.DeviceNode.ServoNode.GetRawFpgaVersion
member.summary: Returns the FPGA Version for the servo node
member.remarks:
The FPGA version register has the following format: TTCCVVRR - TT = FPGA type - CC = Compatibility Code - VV = Firmware Version - RR = Firmware Revision
TT is where the most significant bit indicates the processor type.

member.name: M:Ace.Communication.Services.Link.ActiveVLink.SyncWithController
member.summary: Synchronizes with controller. We need to ensure the controller and the PC are in sync. The controller can sometimes take a long time to respond to an ID command and the responses can actually buffere up. This ensures we get a specific / unique response so we are not getting responses to previous requests.

member.name: T:Ace.Communication.Services.VpTransform
member.summary: A "homogeneous transformation", which describes the offset and orientation of one XYZ coordinate system from another as a single entity.
member.remarks:
An affine, non-scaling transform may be written as
[ xAxis.X yAxis.X zAxis.X offset.X ] [ xAxis.Y yAxis.Y zAxis.Y offset.Y ] [ xAxis.Z yAxis.Z zAxis.Z offset.Z ] [ 0 0 0 1 ]
where xAxis, yAxis, and zAxis are unit vectors specifying the new XYZ axes in the coordinate system of the old XYZ axes, and offset specifies the offset of the new origin from the old origin, along the old axes. A V+ Transform is immutable--once defined, it cannot be changed. This makes it behave much as a value type.

member.name: T:Ace.Communication.Services.VpTransform.Euler
member.summary: Defines the order of Euler angles that are supported by the VpTransform class.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.VpTransform.Euler.Xyz
member.summary: X-Y-Z Euler angles, in which the order of rotations is a rotation about X, followed by a rotation about the "new" Y axis after the initial rotation, followed by a rotation about the "new" Z axis.

member.name: F:Ace.Communication.Services.VpTransform.Euler.Zyz
member.summary: Z-Y-Z Euler angles, in which the order of rotations is a rotation about Z, followed by a rotation about the "new" Y axis after the initial rotation, followed by a rotation about the "new" Z axis.

member.name: T:Ace.Communication.Tftp.TftpServer
member.summary: Simple TFTP Server. Supports multiple concurrent clients.
member.remarks:
Booting a SmartController from TFTP:
Disable autoboot with the hardware or software DIP switches.
At the prompt for the boot device, enter "X" and either Enter (load and go), ^J (verbose load and go), or ^L (verbose load and not go).
Enter the IP address of the TFTP host (in "dotted-decimal" format).
Enter the path to the V+ system on the TFTP host. For example: C:\Adept\Disks\Disk_C\V1603\
SW1 Settings:
SW 1 SW 2 SW 3 SW 4 Interpretation ON ON ON ON No auto boot, all other settings per CompactFlash OFF ON ON ON No auto boot, user interface via serial port ON ON OFF ON No auto boot, user interface via Ethernet AdeptWindows (use IP address in CompactFlash) OFF ON OFF ON No auto boot, user interface via Ethernet AdeptWindows (use default IP address) OFF OFF OFF OFF Operation per CompactFlash and NVRAM settings

member.summary: Checks whether a given string contains a unicode character
member.returns: True if the input string contains at least one unicode character

member.name: M:Ace.Communication.Util.TextUtil.StringToBytes(System.String)
member.summary: Converts a string to bytes. If a unicode character is encountered, 0x0200 (unicode start byte + null byte) is inserted in the byte array before writing the character. When the next ASCII character is encountered, 0x0300 (unicode end byte + null byte) is again inserted in the byte array before writing the ASCII character.

member.name: M:Ace.Communication.Util.TextUtil.BytesToString(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Converts bytes to a string. If a byte array with unicode characters is received, we extract the characters using ASCII encoding until 0x0200 (unicode start byte + null byte) is encountered. Then, extract the subsequent characters using Unicode encoding until 0x0300 (unicode end byte + null byte) is encountered.

member.name: M:Ace.Communication.Util.TextUtil.ConvertASCIIByteToUnicodeBytes(System.Byte)
member.summary: Converts an ASCII 1-byte character to its equivalent unicode 2-byte representation
member.returns: 2-byte unicode representation of the ASCII character
